text: Nearly 70 Illinois nursing homes have reported 10 or more deaths of residents from COVID-19, which has likely also infected more than 7,000 facility workers, according to newly released data. https://t.co/smARlCcR5d

name: chicagotribune
text: Commentary: Fighting against injustice requires building understanding and creating solidarity with the black community, one family, one child, one person at a time. To do so can literally save a life. https://t.co/fqT4jXVTjy

text: A man was arrested in the killing of a Chicago resident following unrest in Cicero earlier this week, authorities said. https://t.co/MdrcjsGwfs

name: chicagotribune
text: DePaul athletic director Jean Lenti Ponsetto is retiring this summer after 18 years, a university spokesman said. Ponsetto ushered DePaul into the Big East Conference in 2005 and oversaw the basketball teams’ move into Wintrust Arena in 2017. https://t.co/LYCzO0lqHC

name: chicagotribune
text: New federal data shows how COVID-19 is ripping through understaffed Illinois nursing homes. https://t.co/85B2adKB3X

name: chicagotribune
text: Three men who were charged with murder months after the fatal shooting of Ahmaud Arbery appeared for their probable cause hearing Thursday by video from jail following a week of angry protests in the U.S. over law enforcement biases against black victims. https://t.co/a9NZs7n81k

name: chicagotribune
text: Construction of a 74-story condo tower designed by Helmut Jahn has been halted, which the project’s developers said was done to prevent the spread of COVID-19. The skyscraper is the first prominent high-rise project to shut down during the pandemic. https://t.co/k4oFvQxAwX

name: chicagotribune
text: J.C. Penney will begin closing 154 of its stores next week, including five Illinois locations, in what it is calling the first phase of its efforts to shrink its footprint https://t.co/fIqsT4hVwu

text: For many in Chicago’s Latino community, the prospect of more people getting out and about sows more anxiety than optimism. https://t.co/5sRnA0YHRt

name: chicagotribune
text:
Two studies, published in renowned scientific journals, that produced astounding results and altered the course of research into the coronavirus pandemic have been retracted because the authors could not verify the data. 

From The New York Times. https://t.co/XKUPz2SWuF

name: chicagotribune
text: “Nuestras vidas como personas marrones están conectadas con las vidas de las personas negras. Nunca tendremos respeto hasta que los negros lo tengan”, dijo una activista, después de la tensión racial se intensificó en el barrio de La Villita. https://t.co/HD1V7dmT34

name: chicagotribune
text: “Our lives as brown people are connected to the lives of black (people). We will never get respect until black people get respect,” one activist told a crowd gathered to show unity in Chicago after racial tensions escalated in Latino neighborhoods https://t.co/93ZbSE5eQg

name: chicagotribune
text: Patrick Mahomes, Saquon Barkley and Michael Thomas are among more than a dozen NFL stars who united to send a passionate video message to the league about racial inequality. https://t.co/5z4APlXGFi

name: chicagotribune
text:
Chicago mom D’Asia Hervey didn’t want to bring her baby to a protest, but her own mom, who has raised three black sons, persuaded her. 

She told her son, “Look at all these people. They’re here for your future.” https://t.co/x7idwnEMDt

name: chicagotribune
text:
Mayor Lori Lightfoot is calling for the firing of a Chicago police officer who was photographed giving protesters the middle finger, as well as those who hide their badge numbers.

“We’re actively at work identifying the officers responsible for that.” https://t.co/vmvEiKD8yY

name: chicagotribune
text:
While acknowledging it’ll ultimately be up to Chicago police Superintendent David Brown, Mayor Lori Lightfoot said, “In my view, they forfeited their right to be Chicago police officers.”

Here’s more on the story: https://t.co/fIVLTYh0PR

name: chicagotribune
text:
